posts.name: 0ri Korngut?
posts.cooked:
Yesterday, during one of the robot’s sessions, Coral fell on Kraken. Since then, the Kraken has not responded or worked with the CAN network.

Is there a solution to this? Or is the Kraken no longer usable?

This worries me a bit, this was the first time we had coral fall on the electronics, and even the first time there are problems…

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
I’m sorry to hear one got whacked, it sucks this happened… But better here than in an actual match I guess…

Was it a swerve motor or somewhere else? Where did the motor take the hit? End? Side?

posts.name: 0ri Korngut?
posts.cooked:
Luckily we use mk4i, So our swerve is relatively protected from blows, and it was somewhere else in the robot.

This was during collection from the source, so the angle of impact on the Kraken was roughly similar to the angle of the source.

posts.name: 9016a
posts.cooked: Maybe try removing the kraken’s cap and retightening the can connections.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: Adding to this, I’d the power and can wires aren’t tightened to spec, they have a chance to slowly come undone. Highly recommend using a torque wrench tighten every wire to the manufacturers specification.

Torquing is a good point.  You will need to purchase an  inlb torque screwdriver.

The conversion for NM to inlb is 8.85 inlb per 1 NM. Motor power connection is torqued to 8inlb CAN connection is torqued to 5inlb

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
1732 had similar troubles with a few X60s when we were prototyping, and those problems vanished when we torqued the CAN leads down.

We bought the right tool so we could tighten them down exactly to spec. I’d encourage folks to have good torque hygeine.

That being said, there used to be a whole lot of screw terminals in the FRC electrical system, and I don’t recall ever seeing someone use a torque driver on a PDB, a Victor, or a Jag

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: So... is that one ugga-dugga or two? Ehh whatever, tight is tight.4.25" wide matte die-cut vinyl sticker.

link_counts.title: Gutentight Sticker - a shade tree mechanic torque spec sticker | blipshift

posts.name: Mannie Dorfan
posts.cooked: We found that some of the shrink sleves on the power cable  protruded too much into the contact area. After trimming contact was much more reliable.
